questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with severe, chronic diarrhoea, failure to thrive, and a rash. His medical history includes a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes mellitus and thyroiditis. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of anti-enterocyte antibodies. Based on these findings, which mechanism is most likely impaired in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Peripheral tolerance

Explanation:

The clinical scenario likely describes IPEX (immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked) due to defective peripheral tolerance.

  • IPEX is an X-linked immune dysregulation disorder that presents in childhood. It occurs due to defects in the FOXP3 gene, which plays a crucial role in peripheral tolerance mediated by CD4+ T regulatory cells.
  • Defects in FOXP3 lead to dysfunctional CD4+ T regulatory cells, impairing their ability to maintain immune tolerance and resulting in autoimmune reactions against various tissues, particularly within the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text:
Match the following processes in immune tolerance with their associated regulators.


	
		
			
			Process
			
			
			Regulators
			
		
		
			
			1. Negative selection
			
			
			a. CD-28
			
		
		
			
			2. Anergy
			
			
			b. FOXP3
			
		
		
			
			3. Deletion by apoptosis
			
			
			c. AIRE
			
		
		
			
			4. Suppression by regulatory T cells
			
			
			d. CD95
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A): 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b.

Explanation:

Negative selection or clonal deletion:

  • Process in which T cells expressing receptors for self-antigens encounter these antigens in the thymus and are then killed by apoptosis.
  • AIRE (autoimmune regulator) is a regulator protein critical for deleting these T cells. A defect in AIRE leads to autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (AIPS).

Anergy:

  • A process where lymphocytes that recognise self-antigens are rendered functionally unresponsive.
  • Binding co-stimulatory signals to CD28 leads to T cell proliferation and differentiation.

Deletion by apoptosis:

  • T cells that recognise self-antigens receive signals that promote their death by apoptosis.
  • Upon recognition of self-antigens, lymphocytes express the death receptor Fas (CD95).

Suppression by regulatory T cells:

  • CD4+/ regulatory T cells prevent immune reactions against self-antigens.
  • Both IL-2 and FOXP3 are required for the functioning of CD4+ regulatory T cells. Mutations in FOXP3 result in an autoimmune disease called IPEX (immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked).

questions.text: Which of the following is an immune-privileged site?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Testis

Explanation:

Among the given options, the testis is an immune-privileged site.

The testis, eye, and brain are called immune-privileged sites because antigens are sequestered/isolated from the immune system without communicating with blood and lymph.

Brain

Blood-brain barrier

Eyes

Blood-ocular barrier

Testes

Blood-testicular barrier
  • These tissues fail to elicit immune responses and are ignored by the immune system.
  • If the antigens of these tissues are released as a consequence of trauma or infection, an immune response will result, leading to prolonged inflammation and injury.
  • This is the postulated mechanism for post-traumatic orchitis and uveitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of fatigue, fever, and weight loss. She also reports joint pain, swelling and a rash, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

Explanation:

  • The patient's clinical presentation suggests systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disorder, but is also a type 2 and type 3 HSN combination (Type 3 HSN> Type 2 HSN)
  • Most sensitive antibody causing SLE: Antinuclear antibody (ANA)
  • Most specific antibody causing SLE: Anti-Smith antibody (ASA)
  • Antibody that is both sensitive and specific: Anti-double-stranded DNA antibody (Anti-dsDNA)

Clinical Manifestations of SLE:

  • Skin: Malar rash (butterfly rash): Present on cheeks and bridge of the nose but sparing the nasolabial regfion.
  • Multi-organ involvement, like:
    • Joints, renal, cardiovascular, pulmonary, neurological and haematological involvements

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents with malaise, joint pain, and fever for the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a malar rash and mouth ulcers. She has significant proteinuria and decreased GFR. Which of the following antibodies are most specific and most sensitive, respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anti-Sm, ANA

Explanation:

  • Based on the above clinical scenario mentioning malar rash and multi-organ involvement, the most likely diagnosis is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • Anti-Smith antibodies (ASA) are most specific for SLE.
  • Anti-double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibodies are most sensitive for SLE.

Marker/Antibody

Clinical Significance

Anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibodies

Highly specific for SLE (<30% of patients)

Anti-dsDNA antibodies

Highly specific for SLE (60-70% of patients); correlates with the disease

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA)

Highly sensitive but not specific for SLE

Anti-Ro (SSA) and Anti-La (SSB) antibodies

Found in SLE and Sjögren syndrome; associated with neonatal lupus

Anti-ribosomal-P antibodies

Specific for neuropsychiatric manifestations in SLE

Anti-histone antibodies

Seen in drug-induced lupus; less specific for SLE

Complements C3 and C4

Low levels indicate complement consumption and disease activity

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with SLE complains of red, frothy urine for the past two months despite being on treatment. Urine analysis shows RBCs and proteins. An image of renal biopsy is given below. Which of the following accurately describes the histopathological findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wire loop lesions

Explanation:

  • Wire loop lesions are a characteristic histopathological finding in lupus nephritis.
    • Wire loop means that capillary loop has become thicker due to subendothelial deposits.
    • Seen more commonly in classes 3,4, and 5 of lupus nephritis (There are a total of 6 classes).

Glomerular crescents (Option C) are seen in crescentic/Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis(RPGN),

Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesion (Option D) is a feature of diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman has had persistent dry eyes and mouth for the past several months. She also reports difficulty in swallowing solid foods and occasional blurred vision. On examination, she has bilateral parotid gland enlargement. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Which antibodies are specific for this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anti La

Explanation:

  • Based on the above clinical scenario, the patient can be diagnosed with Sjogren’s syndrome.
  • Symptoms include blurred vision, difficulty swallowing, decreased taste, cracks and fissures in the mouth, and parotid gland enlargement.
  • Patient presents with: 
    • Dry eyes due to antibodies attacking the lacrimal gland.
    • Dry mouth due to antibodies attacking the lacrimal gland.
  • Antibodies are of 2 types:
    • Anti-SS-A (Anti-Ro) antibodies: Most sensitive
    • Anti-SS-B (Anti-La) antibodies: ​​​​​​​Most specific

Autoantibody

Associated Autoimmune Condition

Anti-Sm (Smith) (Option A)

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) (Option C)

Diffuse systemic sclerosis (scleroderma)

Anti-U1 RNP (Ribonucleoprotein) (Option D)

Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD)

questions.text: A 20-year-old female complains of recurrent episodes of her fingers turning symmetrically white, which are associated with pain and a tingling sensation. This is worse when exposed to cold water and is relieved when she dips her fingers in warm water. The autoimmune panel is negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Primary Raynaud phenomenon

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario describes the Raynaud phenomenon (an exaggerated vasoconstriction of arteries and arterioles in response to cold or emotional stress.

  • The fingers classically show these colour changes in this order:
    • Red: Proximal vasodilation
    • White: Central vasoconstriction
    • Blue: Distal cyanosis.
  • Primary Raynaud's phenomenon is characterized by symmetric episodes of finger whitening induced by cold, resulting from hyper reactive smooth muscle cells in the blood vessel walls. It occurs without an underlying disorder and typically does not lead to ulcers. Tests for autoimmune conditions yield negative results in such cases.
  • Secondary Raynaud's phenomenon results from underlying arterial disease seen in autoimmune disorders like mixed connective tissue disease, CREST syndrome, and SLE. It shows asymmetric finger involvement and progressive worsening of symptoms over time. (Option C)

 

 

Dermatomyositis (Option B) may involve the hands, with classical lesions being Gottron papules (multiple hyperkeratotic, flat, red papules over the dorsum of the metacarpophalangeal joints) and mechanic hands (fissuring with hyperkeratotic papules, scaling, and fissures along the sides of the fingers and palms). Autoimmune panel is positive.

Calcinosis cutis (Option D) is a characteristic lesion of CREST syndrome, referring to the deposition of calcific nodules in the skin of the hands. It is an autoimmune disorder because of anti-centromeric antibody.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman complains of bilateral hand pain and stiffness, especially in the morning. On examination, you notice diffuse thickening and tightening of the skin all over her body. Echo showed pulmonary hypertension. Laboratory tests show positive Anti-SCL-70 antibodies What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Systemic sclerosis

Explanation:

The patient's presentation of diffuse sclerosis and echo showing pulmonary hypertension is highly suggestive of systemic sclerosis, also known as scleroderma.

  • Scleroderma, also known as systemic sclerosis, is a rare autoimmune disease characterized by excessive collagen production, which leads to thickening and hardening of the skin and other organs.

Subtypes In systemic sclerosis:

  • Limited systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome) features calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, oesophagal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia. It is characterized by a positive anti-centromere antibody (option C)
  • Diffuse systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) features widespread skin thickening starting from fingers, positive Anti-SCL-70/Anti-topoisomerase antibody, and extensive organ involvement: GIT dysfunction, musculoskeletal inflammation, scleroderma renal crisis, interstitial lung fibrosis, pulmonary hypertension, and cardiac manifestations.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A): This condition is characterized by symmetrical joint pain and swelling and is distinguished by the presence of rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide.

Osteoarthritis (Option B) is a degenerative joint disease affecting weight-bearing joints without skin involvement or autoimmune features.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive proximal muscle weakness over the past 6 months. On examination, the hip and shoulder girdle muscles have symmetrical weakness. Laboratory investigations show elevated serum creatine kinase (CK) levels. A muscle biopsy reveals endomysial inflammation with CD8+ T lymphocytes and muscle fiber necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Polymyositis

Explanation

The features of progressive proximal muscle weakness along with the findings of endomysial inflammation on biopsy and no dermatological findings, suggest the diagnosis of polymyositis.

In Polymyositis, endomysial inflammation is seen with no skin findings and no atrophy.It presents with proximal muscle weakness.

Dermatomyositis (Option A) also presents with proximal muscle weakness and elevated CK levels, but it typically includes skin manifestations (e.g., heliotrope rash, Gottron's papules on hands, mechanic's hands), which are not mentioned here. Muscle biopsy in dermatomyositis typically shows perifascicular atrophy and inflammation.

Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM) (Option C): Involves the distal muscles. Muscle biopsy shows inclusion bodies (amyloid-like material which forms inclusions in muscle fibres), which are positive for Congo-red staining.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with fatigue, muscle weakness, and joint pain. On examination, she has a rash over her cheeks, along with Raynaud's phenomenon and swollen fingers. Laboratory tests reveal positive anti-U1 RNP antibodies. Which of the following conditions is this patient most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mixed connective tissue disease

Explanation:

Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) is characterised by a combination of features, including muscle weakness, joint pain, a rash over the cheeks (often referred to as a butterfly or malar rash), Raynaud's phenomenon, and anti-U1 RNP antibodies.

  • MCTD features overlap between systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma (systemic sclerosis), and polymyositis.
  • It is characterised by synovitis in the fingers, Raynaud's phenomenon, myositis, and mild renal involvement.
  • Over time, MCTD may progress to classic systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or systemic sclerosis.
  • Antibody: Anti-U1 RNP (ribonucleoprotein) antibody.
  • Treatment: Corticosteroids.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated for proximal muscle weakness. Which of the following is consistent with a diagnosis of polymyositis?

choices.text: CD4+ T cell infiltration in affected tissue

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Endomysial inflammation

Explanation:

Endomysial inflammation is a consistent feature of polymyositis.

  • Polymyositis is an inflammatory myopathy that typically presents with proximal muscle weakness.
  • It is mediated by CD8+ T lymphocytes.
  • Histologically, it is characterized by an endomysial inflammatory infiltrate with patchy necrosis.

Dermatomyositis

  • Histologic findings include ​​​​​​peripheral or peri fascicular infiltrates and atrophy in a segmental pattern.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with fatigue, joint pain, and a rash. A blood test reveals positive anti-nuclear antibodies. Which of the following fluorescence patterns is most commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A

Explanation:

The homogeneous fluorescence pattern of ANA is often associated with SLE, reflecting uniform nucleus staining.

  • The most widely used method for detecting ANAs is indirect immunofluorescence, which can identify antibodies that bind to a variety of nuclear antigens, including DNA, RNA, and proteins (collectively called generic ANAs).
  • The pattern of nuclear fluorescence suggests the type of antibody present in the patient’s serum.
  • Four basic patterns are recognized

Homogeneous or diffuse staining of nuclei

(Option A)

Antibodies reactive with dsDNA, nucleosomes, and histones, and is common in systemic lupus erythematosus

Speckled pattern

(Option B)

Antibodies against various nuclear antigens, including Sm and RNPs

Nucleolar pattern

(Option C)

Antibodies against nucleolar proteins

Anti-centromere antibodies (Option D)

Systemic sclerosis, Sjögren syndrome, and other diseases

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of dermatomyositis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B

Explanation:

Image B represents panniculitis (raised reddish lesions on skin) which is commonly seen in diseases like erythema nodosum.

Dermatomyositis:

  • An inflammatory myopathy that affects skin as well as skeletal muscles.
  • Proximal muscles will be involved.
  • Characteristic rashes include:
    • Gottron papules (Option A) - Raised erythematous rash over metacarphalangeal and interphalangeal joints.

    • Heliotrope rash (Option C) - Erythematous discoloration of eyelids with periorbital edema.

    • Mechanic's hands (Option D) - Presence of fissures/cracks on hands and palms.

    • V-sign (Necklace sign) - Rash on the sun-exposed anterior neck and chest.

    • Shawl sign over the back of the neck and shoulders.

    • Nail bed changes with dilated capillaries.

    • The histological hallmark of dermatomyositis: Perifascicular atrophy (Atrophy of the muscle fibers which are located at the periphery).
